standards_alignment.standard: MS-LS2-4
MS-LS2-2

title: LabVenture Recap
subtitle: Let's Go Back to Lab Venture
intro_copy: Recap the LabVenture experience by reviewing key data visualizations and revisiting the 3 driving questions: What’s happening in the Gulf of Maine? How do we know? Why should we care? Reinforce data practices used in LabVenture to make meaning from data, and set the stage for additional explorations of Earth’s changing climate on other ecosystems in Maine.
overview_copy:
This lesson is designed to follow a class visit to LabVenture—ideally within a week or two of the trip. It is intended to be a classroom discussion, structured around a slide presentation containing data and imagery from LabVenture. The presentation is organized roughly around the sequence of experiences in the LabVenture program.


In addition to reminding students what they did and reinforcing the major takeaway messages from LabVenture, this activity is designed to model a systematic way of thinking about scientific topics that will carry through all of the LabVenture classroom extension activities. This includes asking three basic questions, “What do we know?” “How do we know it?” and “Why does it matter?,” along with the integration of authentic scientific data into each investigation. This activity uses specific topics that students explored together at GMRI to create a foundation for carrying out additional scientific explorations of Maine’s changing ecosystems using data.
learning_outcomes:
After this lesson, students should be able to recognize that:

  • Climate is changing in Maine and globally
  • Change over time and its impacts can be studied and understood by making observations and collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data
  • Climate change impacts me, my community, and people all over the world
  • Understanding climate change and its impacts is a collaborative effort involving professional scientists and members of the community
why_teach:
The goal of this activity is two-fold. First, it provides students with time to reflect on the experience they had at LabVenture, and to discuss what they learned from it. Second, it reinforces the inquiry process in which students engaged throughout the LabVenture experience—asking themselves three fundamental questions, “What do we know?,” “How do we know it?,” and “Why does it matter?” 

The first question, “What do we know?,” is intended to remind students that science is about generating knowledge of the world around us; and that this process allows us, first and foremost, to actually know stuff. In this recap of the LabVenture experience, the question will serve primarily as a reminder of the knowledge they gained there. 

How do we know it?,” reminds students that the stuff they know isn’t just a guess or an opinion—it came from scientists and fishermen making observations, asking questions, conducting experiments, and analyzing data to come to defensible conclusions about the things they study. 

The third question, “Why does it matter?,” challenges students to consider the relevance of this knowledge and these data  to their own lives. As citizens of Maine, the changing oceans are certainly of interest, as fishing and tourism are important drivers of the economy. And as they move beyond this recap into other explorations of regional ecosystems, students may find more intimate connections to their own lives—even if they live in communities far from Maine’s coastline.

chapter.title: Lesson #2
chapter.subtitle: Local Change
chapter.intro_copy: In this lesson, students explore how temperature has changed in Maine, how it is predicted to change over the next 100 years, and how Maine's forecasted future temperature compares to other states.
chapter.learning_outcomes:
• Recognize that data can be organized and represented in different ways to answer different questions
  • Recognize connections between global and local change
  • Use data as evidence to support a claim

file.title: Shape of Change - Teacher Guide 1 PDF

chapter.title: Lesson #1
chapter.subtitle: Global Change
chapter.intro_copy: In this lesson, students explore global air temperature data and practice good habits for interpreting data tables and graphs.
chapter.learning_outcomes:
• Recognize that data can be organized and represented in different ways to answer different questions
  • Recognize connections between global and local change
  • Use data as evidence to support a claim

title: The Shape of Change
subtitle: What does change over time look like?
intro_copy: Students learn that Earth’s temperature is changing. How do we use data to describe the shape of change globally and here in Maine? How do we use data from the past to predict the future?
overview_copy: At LabVenture, students used data to explore how ocean temperature in the Gulf of Maine is changing and how those changes are impacting two key species that live there. In this set of lessons, students will explore global and local air temperature data and use a variety of data representations to determine the shape of change over time—past, present, and future.
learning_outcomes:
After completing this lesson, students should be able to:

  • understand that climate is changing in Maine and globally
  • describe how change over time and its impacts can be studied and understood by making observations and collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data
  • use the overall shape of graphs to interpret long-term trends and short-term variability in time-series data
  • apply good habits for reading and interpreting graphs
why_teach:
During their LabVenture experience, students were introduced to how data are used to understand environmental changes in the Gulf of Maine and and their impacts on two key species that live there. As you and your students prepare to continue studying climate impacts on other ecosystems in Maine, students may need additional practice thinking critically about graphs and identifying patterns in time series data. This activity is designed to help students:

  • develop good habits for reading and interpreting graphs
  • identify and describe variability and trends in data
  • use data as evidence to support a claim
misconceptions:
• Interpreting graphs: Students may interpret graphs incorrectly because they do not carefully examine axis labels, scale, and/or units. Help students practice good habits by encouraging them to begin any and all graph interpretation by carefully reading the title, scale, or axis labels, and asking what the graph could be showing.

  • Students may not have worked with time-series graphs before. Consider using something more familiar, like a timeline, as an analogy. The x-coordinate shows when something happened in time; the y-coordinate shows the measured value at that time.

  • When discussing trends and trend lines, be sure students understand that this is not the same as connecting the dots between data points. A trend or trend line is an imaginary “line of best fit” that you superimpose on top of data to show the general direction of change. Trend lines can also be used to forecast what is most likely to happen in the future.

title: Intertidal Crabs
subtitle: Native and invasive crabs
intro_copy: This guide is intended to provide a suggested learning experience that wraps around contribution to a citizen science Mission and engages students in the full scientific inquiry process. We ask that piloting teachers complete specific lessons from the full experience though we welcome feedback on all curriculum resources.  Outlines of both pathways are in the table below. Numbers in parenthesis indicate the estimated number of class periods for each lesson. Estimates of class time are based on 45-minute class periods.
overview_copy: Protocols must be followed for data contribution. Review protocols and required equipment and materials. Reach out to GMRI staff so we can help you secure materials you might be missing or help you identify local partners who may have the necessary equipment.
why_teach: The protocol requires a field site in a rocky intertidal zone. Crab habitats include primarily moveable rock and seaweed, though salt marsh also makes for an interesting field site. Sandy beach and ledge are not good places to sample. Data also must be collected in the timeframe of an hour before and an hour after low tide. Once you have a rocky intertidal field site selected look at a tide chart. Plan the timing of your unit so that you will be able to collect data in the required timeframe.

chapter.title: Biodiversity Jenga
chapter.intro_copy: Sets up students for understanding importance of collecting data for scientific inquiry.

title: Research Jigsaw
subtitle: Building Context
intro_copy: Students work in teams to gather background information that will provide context for a future fieldwork investigation and help them generate informed predictions. This lesson can be completed on its own, or as part of longer learning module.

chapter.title: Lesson #5
chapter.subtitle: Write a Public Service Announcement
chapter.intro_copy: Students consolidate the evidence they have gathered about the transmission of Lyme disease, its increasing prevalence in Maine, and the climate factors driving that trend to write a community-oriented public service announcement in a creative format.
chapter.learning_outcomes:
• Use data as evidence to support a claim
  • Recognize that data can be organized and represented in different ways to answer different questions
  • Use data visualizations to communicate about and to understand/make sense of a phenomenon

url.title: Teacher Guide - Example Rainfall Trends - T&L

chapter.title: Lesson #4
chapter.subtitle: Rainfall
chapter.intro_copy: At LabVenture and in previous lessons, students have explored how temperature is changing over time, both in the ocean and on land. However, climate is determined by more than just temperature. In this lesson, students will explore how precipitation (rainfall) is changing over time in Maine and what impacts those changes might have on the spread of Lyme disease.
chapter.learning_outcomes:
• Recognize that data can be organized and represented in different ways to answer different questions
  • Use data visualizations to communicate about and to understand/make sense of a phenomenon
  • Use data as evidence to support a claim

chapter.title: Lesson #3
chapter.subtitle: Temperature
chapter.intro_copy: At LabVenture, students learned about how changing ocean temperature impacts where lobster and black sea bass prefer to live. Are changing temperatures on land in Maine impacting where ticks live and spread Lyme disease? In this lesson, students learn about the ideal temperature range for ticks and use data to explore how temperature is changing across Maine. Students will compare temperature data, identify trends, and forecast future temperature conditions for Lincoln and Aroostook Counties to determine if these counties provide suitable conditions for ticks.
chapter.overview_copy: At LabVenture, students learned about how changing ocean temperature impacts where lobster and black sea bass prefer to live. Are changing temperatures on land in Maine impacting where ticks live and spread Lyme disease? In this lesson, students learn about the ideal temperature range for ticks and use data to explore how temperature is changing across Maine. Students will compare temperature data, identify trends, and forecast future temperature conditions for Lincoln and Aroostook Counties to determine if these counties provide suitable conditions for ticks.
chapter.learning_outcomes:
• Recognize that data can be organized and represented in different ways to answer different questions
  • Use data visualizations to communicate about and to understand/make sense of a phenomenon
  • Use data as evidence to support a claim

url.title: Student Activity 2 - Lyme Disease by County - T&L

chapter.title: Lesson #2
chapter.subtitle: Lyme Disease by County
chapter.intro_copy: In the previous lesson, students saw that there is an increasing trend in reported cases of Lyme disease in Maine. In this lesson, students will zoom in even further and investigate how the rate of Lyme disease is changing in their county, and other counties in Maine, over time. Students will be introduced to the two focus counties for the module: Lincoln and Aroostook.
chapter.overview_copy: In the previous lesson, students saw that there is an increasing trend in reported cases of Lyme disease in Maine. In this lesson, students will zoom in even further and investigate how the rate of Lyme disease is changing in their county, and other counties in Maine, over time. Students will be introduced to the two focus counties for the module: Lincoln and Aroostook.
chapter.learning_outcomes:
Data and Scientific Inquiry (This is the work that scientists do!)

  • Data help us understand a problem or phenomenon and can be used as evidence to support scientific claims.
  • Data can be represented and organized in different ways in order to answer different questions or reveal new information.
  • Using data to understand a phenomenon involves being able to read and make sense of data representations (tables, graphs, maps, etc) and models.
chapter.preparations:
• Read this entire guide to familiarize yourself with the flow of the lesson.
  • Do the online activities as a student so you will be prepared to help students if they get stuck.
  • Print copies of Student Sheet: Lesson 2 and the Glossary or prepare to share them electronically with students.
chapter.misconceptions:
• Interpreting graphs: Students may interpret graphs incorrectly because they do not carefully examine axis labels, scale, and/or units. Help students practice good habits by encouraging them to begin graph interpretation by carefully reading the title, scale, and axis labels, then asking what the graph could be showing.
  • Trends: When discussing trends and trend lines, be sure students understand that this is not the same as connecting the dots between data points, nor is it picking points at either end of the data set and drawing a straight line between them. For the purposes of these lessons, a trend describes the shape of a time series graph and provides information about how the data values are changing over time. As you go forward in time, do the data values get bigger, smaller, or stay about the same?
  • Incidence/Rate of Lyme Disease: The calculation of incidence, or rate of Lyme disease is it is referred to in these lessons, and its usage may be challenging for students who are less comfortable with rates. Emphasize the importance of considering population size when making comparisons of Lyme disease cases in different counties. For example, a high population area like Cumberland county can expect to have a great number of total reported cases of Lyme disease compared to a much smaller, more remote county like Aroostook. However, if we look at the number of reported cases per 100,000 people, we are better able to compare how common or how prevalent Lyme disease is in those counties.
chapter.facilitation:
Introduce the lesson.  

Provide students with a brief (~ 5 minute) introduction to the lesson and the goals for the day. Here is a sample script you might follow: 

“In the last lesson we learned the number of cases of Lyme disease is increasing across the Northeast United States and here in Maine. Today we’ll zoom in even further and look at how the number of cases of Lyme disease is changing for individual counties in Maine, including our own.

You’re going to work online [with a partner or in a small group]. Your goals for today are to:

  • Understand how to compare the number of cases of Lyme disease across counties using rates.
  • Use maps, data tables, and graphs to answer different questions about how the rate of Lyme disease is changing across Maine.
  • Describe the trend in the change in the number of cases of Lyme disease for specific counties in Maine.

When you get to your computers, go to the LabVenture website [provide URL] and open Ticks & Lyme Disease Lesson 2: Lyme Disease by County. 

Make sure you read all the instructions carefully before you start clicking around. There will be some questions on the screen for you to answer. Some are just questions to think about or discuss with your partner [or group] and others require you to provide an answer. There will also be new vocabulary words. Words that are orange are defined in the Glossary for this lesson. 

I’ll be walking around the room to help you if you get stuck. When you get to the page that says ‘Stop,’ wait for instructions from me before moving on.”


Have students complete the online activities.

  • It is recommended that students work in pairs or small groups to complete the online activities. Because this lesson is the first in the unit, you may also wish to do some portions as a whole class.
  • While students are working, walk around the room to troubleshoot and answer questions. Below is an outline of the work students will be doing in each of the online activities. Big ideas are listed for each activity. Suggestions for stopping points and discussion prompts for key moments of reflection and synthesis of learning are also provided.

chapter.title: Lesson #1
chapter.display_title: Ticks & Lyme Disease Lesson 1: Lyme Disease in Maine
chapter.subtitle: Lyme Disease in Maine
chapter.intro_copy: In this lesson, students begin their exploration of Lyme disease in Maine. Students use multiple data representations to ask and answer questions about what's happening with the spread of Lyme disease, and share their personal connections to the disease and interaction with ticks. Time permitting, students will learn more about Lyme disease, how it is transmitted, its signs and symptoms, and how to protect themselves and others from tick bites.
chapter.overview_copy: In this lesson, students begin their exploration of Lyme disease in Maine. Students use multiple data representations to ask and answer questions about what's happening with the spread of Lyme disease, and share their personal connections to the disease and interaction with ticks. Time permitting, students will learn more about Lyme disease, how it is transmitted, its signs and symptoms, and how to protect themselves and others from tick bites.
chapter.learning_outcomes:
Climate and Changing Ecosystems

  • Changes in Maine’s ecosystems are local instances of global patterns of change.
Data and Scientific Inquiry (This is the work that scientists do!)
  • Using data to understand a phenomenon involves being able to read and make sense of data representations (tables, graphs, maps, etc) and models.
chapter.preparations:
• Read this entire guide to familiarize yourself with the flow of the lesson.
  • Do the online activities as a student so you will be prepared to help students if they get stuck.
  • Prepare to share the Glossary and Student Sheet: Lesson 1 (Google Doc or Print) with students. Note that in the Google Doc Student Sheet, response boxes are formatted as table cells that will automatically expand to fit entered text.
chapter.misconceptions:
• Interpreting graphs: Help students practice good habits by encouraging them to begin graph interpretation by carefully reading the title, scale, and axis labels, then asking what the graph could be showing.
  • Time series graphs: Students may not have much prior experience with time series graphs. Consider using something more familiar, like a timeline, as an analogy. The x-coordinate shows when something happened in time; the y-coordinate shows the measured value at that time.
  • Trends: When discussing trends and trend lines, be sure students understand that this is not the same as connecting the dots between data points, nor is it picking points at either end of the data set and drawing a straight line between them. For the purposes of these lessons, a trend describes the shape of a time series graph and provides information about how the data values are changing over time. As you go forward in time, do the data values get bigger, smaller, or stay about the same?
  • Incidence (Rate) of Lyme Disease: The use of incidence, or rate of Lyme disease as it is referred to in these lessons, may be challenging for students. Emphasize the importance of considering population size when making comparisons between counties. For example, a high population county may have a greater number of total cases of Lyme disease, but a lower population county could have a higher rate of Lyme per 100,000 people.
chapter.facilitation:
Introduce the lesson.  

Provide students with a brief (~ 5 minute) introduction to the lesson and the goals for the day. Here is a sample script you might follow: 

“Lyme disease, a common tick-borne illness, has been capturing headlines across the country.

Maybe you once found a tick on your clothes after playing outside. Maybe you know someone who has had Lyme disease. Whatever your story, share it with a classmate. Turn to your neighbor and take turns sharing your personal experiences with ticks or Lyme disease. Give students time to share their stories with each other.

What did your stories have in common? What was different? Allow groups to share what they discussed. Encourage a wide range of voices to be heard.

You’re going to work online [with a partner or in a small group]. Your goals for today are to:

  • Understand how the number of cases of Lyme disease is changing in the Northeastern United States and in Maine.
  • Use data visualizations including maps and graphs produced by others to answer questions about the change in the number of cases of Lyme disease.
  • Understand the signs and symptoms of Lyme disease, how the disease is transferred from tick to human, and simple safety tips people can take to protect themselves from tick bites.

    Understand how the number of cases of Lyme disease is changing in the Northeastern United States and in Maine.

    Use data visualizations including maps and graphs produced by others to answer questions about the change in the number of cases of Lyme disease.

    Understand the signs and symptoms of Lyme disease, how the disease is transferred from tick to human, and simple safety tips people can take to protect themselves from tick bites.

    When you get to your computers, go to the LabVenture website and open Ticks & Lyme Disease Lesson 1: Lyme Disease in Maine. 

    Make sure you read all the instructions carefully before you start clicking around. There will be some questions on the screen for you to answer. Some are just questions to think about or discuss with your partner [or group] and others require you to provide an answer. There will also be new vocabulary words. Words that are red are defined in the Glossary for this lesson. 

    I’ll be walking around the room to help you if you get stuck. When you get to the page that says ‘Stop,’ wait for instructions from me before moving on.”

    Have students complete the online activities.

    • It is recommended that students work in pairs or small groups to complete the online activities. Because this lesson is the first in the unit, you may also wish to do some portions as a whole class.
    • While students are working, walk around the room to troubleshoot and answer questions. Below is an outline of the work students will be doing in each of the online activities. Big ideas are listed for each activity. Suggestions for stopping points and discussion prompts for key moments of reflection and synthesis of learning are also provided.

title: Ticks & Lyme Disease
subtitle: Is climate becoming more favorable to ticks in Maine?
intro_copy: Lyme disease, the most common tick-borne illness in the U.S., is on the rise in Maine. Scientists believe that climate plays an important role in the survival of ticks and the spread of Lyme disease. What can we learn from data to find out how climate is changing in Maine and what it might mean for ticks and the spread of Lyme disease?
overview_copy: Lyme disease, the most common tick-borne illness in the U.S., is on the rise in Maine. Scientists believe that temperature and humidity play an important role in the survival of ticks and the spread of Lyme disease. At LabVenture, students used data to explore how ocean temperature in the Gulf of Maine is changing and how those changes are impacting where lobsters and black sea bass prefer to live. In this set of lessons, students will use data to explore how the rate of Lyme disease is changing across the state of Maine as well as how temperature and rainfall are changing in two different Maine counties. Students will use a variety of data representations to make evidence-supported claims about and what those changes might mean for the survival of ticks and the spread of Lyme disease in the future. Students will synthesize what they learn by writing a public service announcement to inform the public about Lyme disease and to persuade them to take action.
learning_outcomes: Students use data visualizations to understand/make sense of a phenomenon.
why_teach: Lyme disease, the most common tick-borne illness in the U.S., is on the rise in Maine. Scientists believe that temperature and humidity play an important role in the survival of ticks and the spread of Lyme disease. At LabVenture, students used data to explore how ocean temperature in the Gulf of Maine is changing and how those changes are impacting where lobsters and black sea bass prefer to live. In this set of lessons, students will use data to explore how the rate of Lyme disease is changing across the state of Maine as well as how temperature and rainfall are changing in two different Maine counties. Students will use a variety of data representations to make evidence-supported claims about and what those changes might mean for the survival of ticks and the spread of Lyme disease in the future. Students will synthesize what they learn by writing a public service announcement to inform the public about Lyme disease and to persuade them to take action.
